name: Representing proportional relationships with an equation

skills.name: Form equations in the form y = kx from direct proportion scenarios
Work out missing quantities from direct proportion problems using an equation in the form y = kx

explanations.A: Not quite, we can calculate the total sales in dollars by multiplying the price of one t-shirt by the number of t-shirts that Luci sells. Also check which variable (ğ‘¥ or ğ‘¦) represents the number of t-shirts that Luci sells.
explanations.B: Nearly! We can calculate the total sales in dollars by multiplying the price of one t-shirt by the number of t-shirts that Luci sells. Check which variable (ğ‘¥ or ğ‘¦) represents the number of t-shirts that Luci sells.
explanations.C: Luci's total sales in dollars are represented by the variable ğ‘¦. We can calculate these total sales in dollars by multiplying the price of one t-shirt ($23) by the number of t-shirts that she sells (ğ‘¥). Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 23 âœ• ğ‘¥ = 23ğ‘¥
explanations.D: Not quite, we can calculate the total sales in dollars by multiplying the price of one t-shirt by the number of t-shirts that Luci sells.

explanations.A: Not quite, we can calculate the total earnings in dollars by multiplying the price of one cup of lemonade by the number of cups that Jackson sells.
explanations.B: Jackson's total earnings in dollars are represented by the variable ğ‘¦. We can calculate these total earnings in dollars by multiplying the price of one cup of lemonade ($2.50) by the number of cups that he sells (ğ‘¥). Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 2.5 âœ• ğ‘¥ = 2.5ğ‘¥.
explanations.C: Nearly! We can calculate the total earnings in dollars by multiplying the price of one cup of lemonade by the number of cups that Jackson sells. Check which variable (ğ‘¥ or ğ‘¦) represents the number of cups that Jackson sells.
explanations.D: Not quite, we can calculate the total earnings in dollars by multiplying the price of one cup of lemonade by the number of cups that Jackson sells. Also check which variable (ğ‘¥ or ğ‘¦) represents the number of cups that Jackson sells.

explanations.A: Not quite, we can calculate the total pieces of candy by multiplying the number of pieces of candy given to one child by the number of children who ring on Tarek's doorbell.
explanations.B: The total pieces of candy given away are represented by the variable ğ‘¦. We can calculate the total pieces of candy by multiplying the number of pieces of candy given to one child (7) by the number of children who ring on Tarek's doorbell (49). Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 49 âˆ™ 7
explanations.C: Not quite, we can calculate the total pieces of candy by multiplying the number of pieces of candy given to one child by the number of children who ring on Tarek's doorbell.
explanations.D: Here, you've tried to add "unlike" variables (the number of children and the number of pieces of candy in one bag). But, we want the total number of pieces of candy given away, when 7 are given to every child.

explanations.A: Not quite, we can calculate the total number of water bottles by multiplying the number of bottles given to one child by the number of children on the trip.
explanations.B: Here, you've tried to add "unlike" variables (the number of children and the number of bottles given to each child). But, we want the total number of water bottles given out, when 3 are given to every child.
explanations.C: Not quite, we can calculate the total number of water bottles by multiplying the number of bottles given to one child by the number of children on the trip.
explanations.D: The total number of water bottles are represented by the variable ğ‘¦. We can calculate the total number of water bottles by multiplying the number of bottles given to one child (3) by the number of children on the trip (42). Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 42 âˆ™ 3

explanations.A: This equation is adding meters and days, which are different units so cannot be added. Uma's total distance over a number of days is the distance she runs on one day multiplied by the number of days that she runs. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.
explanations.B: Not quite, this equation is multiplying Uma's total distance over a number of days by the distance she runs on one day. But, Uma's total distance over a number of days is the distance she runs on one day multiplied by the number of days that she runs. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.
explanations.C: Uma's total distance over a number of days is the distance she runs on one day multiplied by the number of days that she runs. Filling in the information from the question into this word equation gives: 6400 = 100 âœ• ğ‘‘, which is the same as 6400 = 100ğ‘‘.
explanations.D: Not quite, this equation is dividing the distance Uma runs on one day by her total distance over a number of days. But, Uma's total distance over a number of days is the distance she runs on one day multiplied by the number of days that she runs. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.

explanations.A: Not quite, this equation is multiplying Jordan's total distance over a number of days by the distance he throws on one day. But, Jordan's total distance over a number of days is the distance he throws on one day multiplied by the number of days that he throws. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.
explanations.B: This equation is adding feet and days, which are different units so cannot be added. Jordan's total distance over a number of days is the distance he throws on one day multiplied by the number of days that he throws. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.
explanations.C: Not quite, this equation is dividing the distance Jordan throws on one day by his total distance over a number of days. But, Jordan's total distance over a number of days is the distance he throws on one day multiplied by the number of days that he throws. Try substituting in the information from the question into this word equation.
explanations.D: Jordan's total distance over a number of days is the distance he throws on one day multiplied by the number of days that he throws. Filling in the information from the question into this word equation gives: 1200 = 60 âœ• ğ‘‘, which is the same as 1200 = 60ğ‘‘.
